The German Reich proposes an alliance

Mr. President! The military leaders of the Third Reich wish to discuss the possibility of an alliance against the Soviet Union - this could be our chance to strike back against the treacherous Bolsheviks for their discrimination of our beloved fatherland!\n\nShall we sign this alliance
No, stay neutral
Send the Finns Troops!

The Finnish government has accepted our proposition to form an alliance against the Soviet Union.\n\nWith the Finns fighting on the northern flank, our unbeatable troops should face even less resistance when marching straight to Moscow.
Welcome to DiDay's I.C.E: Iron Cross Edition

This mod is meant to be played historically - at least until Pearl Harbour.

In keeping with the historical timeline and to have some actual action, there are scripted historical invasions for the major countries, such as Operation Overlord or the invasions of Italy, Africa or the Pacific Theatre.

You can disable these scripts if you wish, but be aware that the AI is dumb and you may find the game frustrating if Japan doesn't attack the Pacific Islands, or if Italy doesn't defend Libya.

Sometimes you will see that a country annexes itself - this is not a bug.  If an event tells you that you have new units, but you can't see them on the map, check the deployment or production queues.

Thanks for your attention and have a good game!
OK (and I DON'T want scripted invasions)
World War One Fortifications

World War One was fought mainly in deep trenches and fortifications.

After the war most of them were destroyed, but there are still many that remain that can be rebuilt to help defend the country.

You will always see this event no matter the country you are playing - this is my way to add forts in the provinces without altering the history files, which I keep clear for future map mods.

Thanks for understanding.

Having been defeated at the Battle of Midway, the American forces began a full retreat to their naval base on Hawaii, chased by the Imperial Japanese navy.\n\nAfter the invasion and occupation of Hawaii by the Japanese forces, the United States of America was forced to agree to terms of surrender to prevent a naval bombardment of San Francisco and Seattle.

Barbarossa is launched!

Operation Barbarossa (German: Unternehmen Barbarossa) was the code name for Germany's massive invasion of the Soviet Union that began on 22 June, 1941.

Over 4.5 million troops of the Axis powers invaded the USSR along a 2,900 km (1,800 mile) front, from the Baltic to the Black Sea.

It was the largest military offensive in history. In addition to the large number of troops, it also involved 600,000 motor vehicles and 750,000 horses.
Let's crush the Soviet Union!
Stay neutral as long as we can

War preparations against the Soviet Union

According to his orders, on 5 December 1940 Hitler received military plans for the invasion of Soviet Union, and approved them all, with the start scheduled for May 1941. On 18 December 1940, Hitler signed War Directive No. 21 to the German High Command for an operation now codenamed 'Operation Barbarossa' stating: 'The German Wehrmacht must be prepared to crush Soviet Russia in a quick campaign'.\n\nChoosing to prepare the Wehrmacht will grant the Soviet Union a -75% organisation surprise-penalty at the start of Operation Barbarossa.
Prepare the troops for war
No need to.
Karelia is ours again!

We have achieved our goals and re-captured our Finnish territory from the Soviets. Our high command suggests to negotiate a separate peace with the Soviet Union, as our troops may not be ready for a fight deep in enemy territory.\n\nShall we send one of our diplomats and risk upsetting the Germans
Peace with Finland

Due to the inability of our local command, Finland was able to re-gain control over Karelia.

With Finland in the Axis and being successful, our northern flank is at a serious risk now, as the Germans could use Finland as a second bridgehead.

Maybe we should concentrate on Germany now and deal with the Finns later

Sino-German cooperation

China's urgency to modernize its military and national defence industry, coupled with Germany's need for a stable supply of raw materials, put the two countries on the road of close relations from the late 1920s to the late 1930s.\n\nAlthough intense cooperation lasted only from the Nazi takeover of Germany in 1933 to the start of the Sino-Japanese war in 1937, and concrete measures at industrial reform started in earnest only in 1936, it had a profound effect on Chinese modernization and the capability of the Chinese to resist the Japanese in the war.
Agree to continue it
Stop it
Sino-German cooperation
We have a deal with them...
Splendid
Second Sino-Japanese War

The outbreak of the Second Sino-Japanese War in July 1937 destroyed much of the progress and promises made in the nearly ten years of intense Sino-German cooperation. With the fall of Nanking and the Japanese making further gains, we are now at the crossroads of deciding between upholding our strong economic ties with the Chinese or siding with the Empire of Japan, which seems to be far more capable of resisting the Bolshevist threat in the Far East.
Stop the trade with China
Continue!
End of the Sino-German Cooperation
We have been upholding our strong economical ties with the Chinese government, but now it seems like we've been betting on the wrong horse and should side with the Japanese instead.
So be it!
End of the Sino-German Cooperation
The Germans have decided to end our strong economical ties and side with the Japanese instead. It seems like they don't believe in our capability to defend our country any more.
Their loss...

Anti-Air-Aircraft installation are needed to protect our airfields against enemy planes. So lets build some.\n\n§RPlace the buildings manually on top in building Q and the next day buildings are done§b

50 Cruisers and 95 Light Tanks from the three tank regiments (3rd and 7th Hussars and 2nd RTR), followed by 2nd Rifle Brigade, 4th RHA and a battery of anti-tank guns from 106th RHA.  By 1530 hrs, 11th Hussars had cleared the fort at Msus of the Italian rearguard, but it was realised that the tanks were moving too slowly. It was decided that the faster vehicles and the infantry of the Rifle Brigade, in Bren Gun Carriers, would join the 11th Hussars, who were now far ahead of the main force.\n\nThe force was placed under the command of Lt-Colonel John Combe (11th Hussars) and was therefore called Combeforce.

During the Third Battle of Kharkov, Meyer's battalion frequently co-operated with Wünsche's SS-Panzer-Regiment 1, Theodor Teddy Wischs SS-Panzergrenadier Regiment 2 and Joachim Peiper's III. Battalion, SS-Panzergrenadier Regiment 2.  These ad hoc Kampfgruppen acted like fire brigades, rushing from one crisis point to another, rescuing trapped German troops and capturing Soviet officers.  Meyers battalion captured the entire command staff of a Soviet division near Jeremejewka and Aleksandrowka.

In the final phase of the capture of Kharkov, the Leibstandarte's role was to capture the huge central plaza, called Red Square. Meyer, Wünsche and Peiper all led Kampfgruppen which were to take responsibility of capturing the city.  Meyer led his battalion in a high speed charge to the square, capturing part of it before being cut off by Soviet defenders.

Meyer and his grenadiers held their ground against vastly larger Soviet forces until they were relieved by Peipers Kampfgruppe on 13 March.  Together with Peipers Kampfgruppe and the rest of Teddy Wischs regiment, Meyers battalion finally cleared the city centre after a desperate and bloody fight.  In honour of this action, Red Square was renamed Platz der Leibstandarte.

In early March, Witt's regiment now took part in the Third Battle of Kharkov.  Witt's force was reinforced with tanks, artillery and assault guns, and was given the task of attacking from the North.  The force, renamed Kampfgruppe Witt, was to form one of three pincers which would destroy Mobile Group Popov and recapture Kharkov.

The attack got underway on 2 March, and by 10 March KG Witt had reached the suburbs of Kharkov.  After ferocious fighting near Dergatschi, Witt broke through and advanced into the city centre, fighting alongside Kurt Meyer's Kampfgruppe Meyer.

Over the next few days, the Kampfgruppen of Witt and Meyers' saw intense fighting, and were cut off several times inside the city.  Despite this, they held and Kampfgruppe Peiper under Joachim Peiper reached them and together the three Leibstandarte units annihilated the Soviet defenders.

$MONARCHTITLE$, it is time to hit the enemy hard!  The 2nd Cavalry Group has assembled in Norwich, England, and are ready to meet the Jerrys head-on!\n\nHistorically: During World War II," this regiment (under the designation "2nd Cavalry Group"," Mechanized") landed in France in July 1944", becoming part of General Patton's Third Army. During this period," the regiment became known as the "Ghosts of Patton's Army" due to their ability to conduct reconnaissance", materializing seemingly at will behind German lines. The regiment made the deepest penetration of the war, arriving in Czechoslovakia before finally linking up with Soviet forces heading west. Under the leadership of Colonel Charles H. Reed, the regiment rescued the famous Lipizzaner stallions from the combat zone and brought them to safety in Germany. At the end of the war, the unit was re-designated, yet again, as the 2nd Constabulary Regiment, and eventually the 2nd Armored Cavalry Regiment in 1948.

$MONARCHTITLE$," it is time to hit the Japs hard!  The 158th Regimental Combat Team (RCT) is ready to deploy to Papua New Guinea.

"One of America's most colorful and least known soldiers of World War II is the Bushmaster...His tactics are borrowed from native jungle fighters", the American Indian, British commandos, exponents of judo and the Shanghai underworld...(He uses) machetes, curved knives, tommy guns, high-powered rifles, and hand grenades...His average age is 22 and his favorite weapon is the long-bladed machete...With his fellow Bushmasters, he disappears from civilization for weeks at a time. The men know how to sustain themselves on wild fare supplemented by (jungle rations) carried in their packs. When they are not testing their camouflage against aerial observers, making camp in a swamp, or working out an intricate code of communications," they are practicing jujitsu or improve on the native's technique with the machete. The Bushmaster bows to no man in the art of hand-to-hand fighting and any unwary (enemy) who crosses his path would probably never know what hit him."

- Popular Mechanics Magazine", 1943

$MONARCHTITLE$, it is time to hit the enemy hard!  The 370th Regimental Combat Team has assembled at Ft. Huachuca, Arizona, and are ready to meet the Jerrys head-on!

Historically: The 370th Infantry Regiment arrived in Naples, Italy on 1 August 1944, attached to the Task Force 42 at US 1st Armored Division. The 370th entered combat on 24 August 1944. It participated in the crossing of the Arno River, the occupation of Lucca and the penetration of the Gothic Line, in the persecution of an enemy which was retreating of that area. It was later was attached to the US 92nd Division at the Task Force 45, the US 5th Army unit responsible for the Ligurian coastal sector, the left flank of Allied troops in Italy.

On 1 April, the 370th RCT and the attached 442nd RCT (Nisei) attacked in the Ligurian coastal sector and drove rapidly north against light opposition of German 148th Infantry Division supported by Italian coastal units. The 370th took over the Serchio sector and pursued a retreating enemy from 18 April until the collapse of enemy forces, 29 April 1945. Elements of the 92nd Division entered La Spezia and Genoa on the 27th and took over selected towns along the Ligurian coast until the enemy surrendered, 2 May 1945. Between August 1944 and May 1945 the 92nd Division suffered 3,200 casualties, factoring losses from units attached to the Division brings the totals up to 5,000 casualties

$MONARCHTITLE$, it is time to hit the enemy hard!  The 503rd Parachute Regimental Combat Team has assembled at Ft. Benning, Georgia, and are ready to meet our enemies head-on!

Historically: The 503rd Parachute Regimental Combat Team, began with the activation of the 503rd Parachute Battalion in Fort Benning, Georgia on 21 August 1941. The Battalion was the third of four Parachute Battalions formed prior to the beginning of World War II.

Later the unit was expanded into a Combat Team with the assignment of the 462d Parachute Artillery Battalion on 29 March 1944 and the 161st Parachute Engineer Company on 13 September 1944.

During its more than three years service in the Southwest Pacific Theater, the 503rd served in five major combat operations. A number of other missions were planned but called off by higher headquarters.

$MONARCHTITLE$, it is time to hit the enemy hard!  The 1st Marine Parachute Regimental Combat Team has assembled near San Diego, California, and are ready to meet our enemies head-on!

Historically: The Paramarines (also known as Marine paratroopers) was a short-lived specialized combat unit of the United States Marine Corps, trained to be dropped from planes by parachute. Marine parachute training which began in New Jersey in October 1940 ended with the parachute units being disbanded at Camp Pendleton, California in February 1944. Paratroopers received a significantly increased salary after completing training, so there was no shortage of volunteers, although all were required to be unmarried. Standards of fitness were high, and 40% failed the training course.

Apart from a small group including Peter Julien Ortiz who were parachuted into France as part of an Office of Strategic Services team to support the French Resistance, the Paramarines never dropped by parachute into combat, but were utilized during beach raids in the Pacific campaign, including at Guadalcanal. Paramarines at San Diego were transferred to the 5th Marine Division which landed on Iwo Jima on February 19, 1945.

$MONARCHTITLE$, the 517th Parachute Regimental Combat Team (PRCT) is ready to deploy for training at Camp Toccoa, in the North Georgia mountains. Historically:

The 517th PRCT was one of the U.S. Army's first elite combat units.  The 517th PRCT was formed when the 517th Parachute Infantry Regiment was combined with the 460th Parachute Field Artillery Battalion and the 596th Parachute Combat Engineer Company.

The 517th saw most of its combat in Italy, Southern France, and the Battle of the Bulge as an independent unit.  During its relatively brief lifetime, the 517th Regimental Parachute Combat Team collected one Medal of Honor, six Distinguished Service Crosses, five Legions of Merit, 131 Silver Stars, 631 Bronze Stars, two Air Medals, four Soldiers Medals, 17 French Croix De Guerre, and 1,576 Purple Hearts, at the cost of 252 killed.
The Third Reich

To the north, Germany was bounded by the North Sea, Denmark and the Baltic Sea. To the east, it was divided into two and bordered Lithuania, the Free City of Danzig, Poland and Czechoslovakia. Austria and Switzerland lay to the south, and to the west it touched France, Luxembourg, Belgium, the Netherlands, the Rhineland and the Saarland.

Despite all our valiant efforts, the city of Warsaw is now controlled by the Soviets.\n\nYou are now able to trigger the Totaler Krieg (Total War) decision on the Diplomatic Screen.
The war is not going well
Schwerer (Heavy) Gustav and Dora

Schwerer (Heavy) Gustav and Dora were the names given to two massive German 80 cm K (E) railway siege guns.

They were developed in the 1930s by Krupp Armaments in order to destroy heavily fortified positions, such as the Maginot forts.

Weighing nearly 1,350 tonnes each, they could fire seven tonne shells to a range of 37 kilometres (23 miles).  They were the largest calibre rifled weapon in the history of artillery to see actual combat, and fired the heaviest shells of any artillery piece.

If you decide to build these units, you will be able to deploy them in a few months.
I want to build Gustav
I want to build Gustav and Dora
I'm not interested
Raise the Brandenburgers Commandos

Units of the Brandenburgers operated on almost all fronts - the invasions of Poland, Denmark and Norway, the Battle of France, Operation Barbarossa, in Finland, Greece and the invasions of Crete, Romania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia.  Some units were sent to infiltrate India, Afghanistan, Middle East countries and South Africa.  They also trained for Operation Felix (the planned seizure of Gibraltar), and Operation Sealion.  They had stunning successes early in the war acting as advance units capturing strategic bridges, tunnels, forts, and rail yards in Poland and the Netherlands.\n\nYou will receive three units of Brandenburgers: the first in 1938, the second in early 1940 and the last one in the middle of 1940. After being deployed, you will need to give them time to upgrade before they will be fully combat capable.
One
Two
Three
Build amphibious armour for Operation Sealion

Ordered by the Heereswaffenamt, the Landwasserschlepper was intended as a lightweight river tug with some capacity to operate on land.

Designed by Rheinmetall-Borsig of Düsseldorf, the hull was very like a motor launch, and it resembled nothing more than a tracked boat, down to the twin rear-mounted tunnelled propellers.

On land, it rode on steel-shod tracks with four pairs of bogies per side.  It was intended to aid river crossing and bridging operations.  It had a capacity for 20 passengers and was operated by a crew of 2.
Let's order three of them!
I'm not interested.

The Landwasserschlepper is ready.

The Minister of Armaments is pleased to inform you that the Landwasserschlepper is ready for service and deployed at Berlin. After being deployed, you will need to give them time to upgrade before they will be fully combat capable.
Heavy assault guns for urban warfare

The Sturmpanzer IV (also known as Sturmpanzer 43 or Sd.Kfz. 166) was a German armoured infantry support gun based on the Panzer IV tank chassis used in the Second World War.

It was used at the Battles of Kursk, Anzio, Normandy, and helped to put down the Warsaw Uprising in 1944.

It was known by the nickname 'Brummbär' (Sorehead) by Allied intelligence, a name not used by the Germans - German soldiers nicknamed it the 'Stupa', a contraction of the term 'Sturmpanzer'.
Sturmpanzer IV ready

The Minister of Armament is pleased to inform you that the Sturmpanzer IV Brummbär are ready and deployed at Berlin. After being deployed, you will need to give them time to upgrade before they will be fully combat capable.
Extend the Siegfried Line

The original Siegfried line (Siegfriedstellung) was a line of defensive forts and tank defences built by Germany at a section of the Hindenburg Line in northern France during World War I.\n\nWe have the opportunity to extend it from Switzerland to Kalkar in order to defend against a western assault.
Dig in!
No need to.
Fortify the Siegfried Line
The Siegfried Line is solid, but it is not as strong as the French Maginot Line.\n\nWe now have the opportunity to further strengthen the forts and to build additional anti-aircraft defences.
Dig in more!
Equip the Siegfried Line
Since the war seems to be fought in the sky now, our generals recommend we equip the Siegfried Line with more AA guns and radar installations.\n\nThe Allied air forces shall not remain a threat.
Build AA defenses!
We've lost control of Paris!

With Allied progress in France, the war situation in the west became critical. On August 24,1944, Hitler issued a directive for the renewed construction of the Siegfried Line.  20,000 forced labourers and members of the Reichsarbeitsdienst (Reich Labour Service), most of whom were 14 to 16-year-old boys, attempted to re-equip the line for defence purposes. Local people were also conscripted, mostly building anti-tank ditches.\n\nRegardless, their efforts ended in failure as a result of Allied air supremacy.  During construction it was already clear that the bunkers could no longer hope to withstand newly developed deep penetrating tactics.  At the same time as the Siegfried Line was reactivated, small concrete 'Tobruk' bunkers (named after the Libyan port) were built along the border of the occupied areas.  These bunkers were mostly dugouts for single soldiers.
Take apart the French Maginot Line
We need concrete and supplies for the Atlantikwall (Atlantic Wall).  Let's salvage the Maginot Line to get what we need.
Paris is taken!

On 14 June 1940, five weeks after the start of the Battle of France, an undefended Paris (declared an open-city by its governor) fell to advancing German forces. In celebration, the Germans marched past the Arc de Triumph on the 140th anniversary of Napoleon's victory at the Battle of Marengo.
Join the war on the side of Germany!
Keep neutral for now
The Italian invasion of France

The Italian invasion of France in June 1940 was a small scale invasion that started near the end of the Battle of France during World War II. The goal of the Italian offensive was to take control of the Alps mountain range, the region around Nice, and take over the French colonies in North Africa. The offensive did not meet its planned goals, with the Italian forces making only limited headway on all fronts.
Fight on our side!
We don't want you for the moment
Hungary wants to join the Tripartite Pact.

The Hungarian Government under Admiral Miklós Horthy wishes to sign the Tripartite-Pact and thereby to become a full member of the Axis alongside Germany, Italy and Japan.\n\nAfter the First World War, Hungary (as part of the dissolved Austro-Hungarian Empire) had lost huge amounts of its national territory and now hopes to regain them by implementing strong pro-German politics.
Welcome into the Axis
Romania wishes to join the Tripartite Pact.

The Romanian Government under General Ion Antonescu wishes to sign the Tripartite Pact and thereby become a member of the Axis.\n\nThe Romanians signed the pact to protect themselves from Soviet aggression and with hopes to re-capture Bessarabia from the Soviet Union.
Bulgaria wants to join the Axis.

The Bulgarian Government under King Boris wishes to sign the Tripartite Pact and thereby become a member of the Axis.  After Hitler assured the Bulgarians of large territorial returns, the country was willing to fight for the German hegemony over Europe and the Soviet Union.
Operation Barbarossa

Operation Barbarossa (German: Unternehmen Barbarossa) was the code name for Germany's invasion of the Soviet Union during World War II that began on 22 June 1941. Over 4.5 million troops of the Axis powers invaded the USSR along a 2,900 km (1,800 mile) front.

Winter clothes for our soldiers

Our generals recommend we equip our army with winter clothes and special equipment before the Russian winter sets in. This seems defeatist and a long war is not what we or the Fuhrer expects.

If we choose not to equip them, our infantry will maintain their good order, gaining a boost in morale and organisation.

If we do choose to equip them, our nation and infantry will be downhearted that we expect the war to go on longer than expected.  Many trains, trucks and horses will need to be diverted to this task, slowing resupply and troop movement, but if we have to fight during the winter our men and weapons will be much better protected.

Even Napoleon was blocked by the Russian 'General Winter'.\n\nWe didn't learn from this and equip our troops appropriately, so we will lose a lot of men on the Eastern Front due to attrition over the next few months.

Barbarossa Winter Infrastructure

Our Generals report that one of their major logistical problems is the different railway gauge the Russians have compared to ours.  German trains simply can't use the wider Russian rails.

Shall we do something about this

Our soldiers would benefit from better supply throughput.

Build more tank destroyers from spare Tiger tank chassis

Porsche AG had manufactured about one hundred chassis for their proposal for the Tiger tank, the 'Porsche Tiger' in the Nibelungenwerk factory in St. Valentin, Austria.  Since the competing Henschel Tiger design was chosen for production, the Porsche chassis were no longer required for Tiger Tank production. It was therefore decided that the Porsche chassis were to be used as the basis of a new heavy tank destroyer mounting Krupp's newly developed 88 mm Pak 43/2 anti-tank gun.  This precise long-range weapon was supposed to take out enemy tanks before they reached their own optimal firing range.  Ninety-one chassis were converted.  In terms of kills per loss, the 'Elefant' might well have been the most successful tank destroyer employed during the war, reaching an ratio of approximately 10:1.
Ja, build them!
Nein. Victory is at hand, why waste resources
New units ready to deploy mein Fuehrer!

In 1943 89 Panzerjaeger Tiger (P) 'Elefant / Ferdinand' (Sd.Kfz. 184) were assigned to schwere Panzerjaeger Abteilung 653 and 654, in preparation for the Kursk offensive (Operation 'Zitadelle').  During the Kursk offensive through November of 1943, Ferdinands from sPzJagAbt 653 destroyed some 320 Soviet tanks and only lost 13 of their own number, while entire 656 sPanzerjager Regiment destroyed some 502 Soviet tanks and 100 other vehicles.  Ferdinands proved to be very effective when employed behind the front-lines.
Create SS-Jagdverbände

SS-Jagdverbände were small units of up to 3,000 men, put together from Heer, Luftwaffe, SS, Brandenburger and even Kriegsmarine personnel.\n\nThey were primarily used for anti-partisan duty and for carrying out sabotage and reconnaissance behind enemy lines.
Train them!

Paratroopers for the SS

Himmler supposedly got the idea to form an SS-Fallschirmjäger battalion in September 1943 after Operation Oak, although evidence suggests that SS troops were undertaking parachute training as early as 1937.

Operation Oak (Unternehmen Eiche) was launched on 12 September, 1943 and included an airborne raid on the Campo Imperatore Hotel at Gran Sasso, Italy.  The operation was planned by Kurt Student and lead by Otto Skorzeny by command of German dictator Adolf Hitler.  During this raid, a group of German parachutists aided by a daring glider-based assault freed deposed Italian dictator Benito Mussolini without firing a single shot.

In October 1943, orders were given by Führer HQ to raise an SS airborne formation.
Ja, the SS needs commandos like these.
Nein, that would upset Goering and his beloved Luftwaffe.

Assault troops for urban warfare

During the Battle for Stalingrad the Germans launched Operation Hubertus, the last offensive effort of the German 6th Army to conquer Stalingrad between 11 and 19 November 1942.

Assault troops prepared for the onslaught and Pioneer troops, specializing in urban warfare, were flown in.

The Pioneers would spearhead the final attempt to capture the city.

'...Why not push ahead  Because I don't want a second Verdun.  I'd rather fight with small assault units.  Time is not a factor. - Adolf Hitler," November 1942."
Czechoslovakia accepts the inevitable.

On September 29, the Munich Agreement was signed by Germany, Italy, France, and Britain.  The Munich Agreement stipulated that Czechoslovakia must cede the Sudetenland territory to Germany.

Due to this agreement, where Czechoslovakia was not even represented, Edvard Bene resigned as president of the Czechoslovak Republic on October 5,1938, and was succeeded by Emil Hácha.  On March 12, 1939 a group of Slovaks declared independence as the satellite state of Slovakia under Jozef Tiso.

Hitler forced Hácha to surrender what remained of Bohemia and Moravia to German control on 15 March 1939.
We should wait for March 1939, then....

Raise Volksgrenadier Divisions.

Volksgrenadier was the name given to a type of German Army division formed in the Autumn of 1944 after the major defeats of Army Group Center to the Soviets in Operation Bagration and the Fifth Panzer Army to the Allies at Normandy.

The name itself was intended to build morale, appealing at once to nationalism (Volk) and Germany's older military traditions (Grenadier).  Around 50 divisions were formed late in the war.

Volksgrenadiers and Volksgrenadier divisions should not be confused with the Volkssturm, who were an entirely different entity.
Let's raise them (53 divisions)
The situation is under control
We have been attacked by Germany!

'Operation Weserübung' was the code name for Nazi Germany's assault on Denmark and Norway during the Second World War.

On the early morning of 9 April 1940  Wesertag (Weser Day)  Germany invaded Denmark and Norway, ostensibly as a preventive manoeuvre against a planned, and openly discussed, Franco-British occupation of both these countries.  After the invasions," envoys for the Germans informed the governments of Denmark and Norway that the Wehrmacht had come to protect their countries' neutrality against Franco-British aggression.

The invasion of Denmark met with only two hours of military resistance before the Danish government surrendered."
Surrender to Germany
Keep fighting!
Denmark surrenders!

Operation Weserübung was the code name for Nazi Germany's assault on Denmark and Norway during the Second World War.\n\nOn the early morning of 9 April 1940  Wesertag (Weser Day)  Germany invaded Denmark and Norway, ostensibly as a preventive manoeuvre against a planned, and openly discussed, Franco-British occupation of both these countries.  After the invasions," envoys for the Germans informed the governments of Denmark and Norway that the Wehrmacht had come to protect their countries' neutrality against Franco-British aggression."
Wise decision - Annex
Wise decision - Puppet
Occupy the country
An independent Serbia

In 1941, in spite of domestically unpopular attempts by the Government of Yugoslavia to appease the Axis Powers, Nazi Germany, Fascist Italy, and other Axis states invaded Yugoslavia.\n\nAfter the invasion, the Kingdom of Yugoslavia was dissolved and Serbia was put under a German Military administration," with a joint German-Serb government including Milan Nedic as Head of the Government of National Salvation."
Release Serbia as a puppet of Germany
Keep the lands
Decide that later (a decision appears)
Begin the creation of Croatia

The German and Italian invasion of 6 April 1941 achieved victory over the Royal Yugoslav Army in little more than ten days, ending with their unconditional surrender on April 17.\n\nThe territory of Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and the region of Syrmia became a puppet-state of Nazi Germany called the Independent State of Croatia.  Istria, the port city of Rijeka, and a portion of Dalmatia up to Split were occupied by Italy. Baranja and Medjumurje were occupied by Hungary.
Release Croatia as a puppet
Secret Weapons 3x1000 Projekt

The Horten Ho IX often called Ho 229, or Go 229 due to the identity of the chosen manufacturer of the aircraft (Gothaer), was a late-World War II prototype flying wing fighter/bomber, designed by Reimar and Walter Horten and built by Gothaer Waggonfabrik.

It was a personal favourite of German Luftwaffe chief Reichsmars4chall Hermann Goering, and was the only aircraft to come close to meeting his '1000,1000, 1000' performance requirements (1,000 kilograms of bombs (2,200 lb),1,000 kilometres range (620 miles),1,000 kilometres an hour).

Its speed was estimated at 1,024 km/h (636 mph) and its ceiling 15,000 meters (49,213 ft).
German secret weapon 3x1000 Projekt
Secret Weapons Jägernotprogramms

Heinkel's He 162 Volksjäger People's Fighter was a German single-engine, jet-powered fighter aircraft fielded by the Luftwaffe late in World War II.

Designed and built quickly, and made primarily of wood, as metals were in very short supply and prioritised for other aircraft," the He 162 was nevertheless the fastest of the first generation of Axis and Allied jets.

Volksjäger was the Reich Air Ministry's official name for the He 162."
German secret weapon Jägernotprogramms
Secret Weapon Amerika Bomber

The Amerika Bomber project was an initiative of the Reichsluftfahrtministerium, the Nazi Germany Air Ministry, to obtain a long-range bomber aircraft for the Luftwaffe that would be capable of striking the continental United States from Germany, a distance of about 5,800 km (3,600 miles) away.
German secret weapon Amerika Bomber

Since war broke out, maritime commerce is no longer safe and a lot of ships are wasting alongside quays with no use.\n\nMaybe we should convert them to troop transports
Convert them

Foreign Wehrmacht recruitment
This will allow the Wehrmacht to recruit troops from all over Europe. You will occasionally receive an event which activates brigades or adds manpower to the pool.

column1: ############ WAFFEN-SS EVENTS ########### Based upon Jared Torval 081306's work

column2: Schutz-Staffel

In 1936, the SS consisted of three combat regiments: the Leibstandarte SS Adolf Hitler, Germania, and Deutschland.

During the game, if you decide to, you will receive some events and decisions regarding the SS and its historical divisions both foreign and Germanic. Sometimes you will have to merge brigades and divisions by yourself. For example, with the SS Das Reich, which you will receive bit by bit (starting with the Deutschland and Germania regiments).

You also have the opportunity to disable all the SS events and decisions.
Activate the SS
I don't want SS in my game! (deactivate all SS related stuff)
1,2, and 3 Standarten SS-Totenkopfverbände (SS-Death's Head units.

1 SS-Totenkopf-Standarte, later Totenkopf-Infanterie-Regiment 1, formed in autumn 1939 with H.Q. and three battalions as part of SS-Totenkopf Division. 2 SS-Totenkopf-Standarte, later Totenkopf-Infanterie-Regiment 2, formed in autumn 1939 with a H.Q. and three battalions as part of the SS-Totenkopf Division. 3 SS-Totenkopf-Standarte, later Totenkopf-Infanterie-Regiment 3, formed in autumn 1939 with a H.Q. and three battalions (personnel for which came in part from the former 3 SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 'Thuringen') as part of the SS-Totenkopf Division. It also absorbed the infantry from the former SS-Heimwehr-Danzig. ! IMPORTANT ! This division has a long event chain of refits and upgrades so beware that removing units or renaming any of the brigades will stop these events occurring.
Creation of the Waffen SS

In March 1940, after an agreement between the Army and the SS, the title of Waffen SS was officially created. Himmler gained approval for the Waffen-SS to form its own high command, the Kommandoamt der Waffen-SS within the SS-Führungshauptamt. You have two choices of command structure, an SS theatre HQ for totally independant command or an SS Army Group HQ which can be attached to an existing Theatre.
SS Theatre HQ
No need for another HQ
SS-Standarte 'Der Fuhrer'

SS-Standarte Der Fuhrer was formed March 1938 in Vienna as SS-Standarte 3 following the German annexation of Austria. It was made up of Austrian volunteers around a cadre from SS-Standarte Deutschland.  It was renamed SS-Standarte Der Führer at the Parteitag in Nuremberg 1938 when it also received its Deutschland Erwache standard.\n\nThe regiment took part in the occupation of Czechoslovakia and later served as a guard regiment in Prague, as Wach-Regiment des Reichsprotektors von Boehmen und Mähren.
SS-Division Leibstandarte SS 'Adolf Hitler' (LSSAH)

The SS-Division Leibstandarte Adolf Hitler (LSSAH) was initially formed in 1934 from Hitler's bodyguard, and was seen by many as the elite division within the Waffen-SS.  It was the first of the four initial SS-Standarten (Regiments), the other three being Germania, Deutschland and Der Führer - which formed the SS-Verfügungstruppe," later the 2nd SS Division 'Das Reich.'\n\nIt took part in the purge of Ernst Roehm and other enemies of Hitler during the "Night of Long Knives" together with Landespolizeigruppe General Goering"," being motorised and expanded in October 1934 as a reward for its loyalty and services.  It was reinforced in June 1941 after the fall of Yugoslavia."
You have to manually attach this brigade to the old LSSAH brigade
1. SS-Panzer Division LSSAH Reinforcements!

LSSAH took part in Unternehmen Barbarossa attached to Heeresgruppe Süd and saw action at Kiev and Rostov.

It was then transferred to France for refitting during 1942 and was upgraded to a Panzergrenadier-Division.

It returned to the Eastern Front in 1943 and fought at Kharkov and Kursk.  After the failure at Kursk, the LSSAH was sent to Italy on anti-partisan duty but it was soon sent back to the Eastern front, this time as a Panzer Division.
You have to manually attach this brigade to the LSSAH Division
We don't need this
2. SS-Panzer Division 'Das Reich'

The 2nd SS Panzer Division Das Reich was the most successful Waffen-SS division in terms of Knight's Crosses awarded," and was formed from the SS-Verfügungstruppe which comprised of three of the initial SS-Standarten.

The formation was given the designation "Reich" in 1940"," and finally became "Das Reich" in 1942.

Its most famous commander was Paul 'Papa' Hausser", and the division's Panzertruppen counted among their number Ernst Barkmann," probably the most famous Panther commander of the war."
You have to regroup the units manually
3.SS-Panzer Division 'Totenkopf'

The 3rd SS-Panzer Division Totenkopf (Death's Head) was initially seen as the black sheep among the elite Waffen-SS Panzer Divisions due to it's initial formation in 1939 around a core of one-time concentration camp guards. By the time of it's designation as a full-fledged armoured division, it had become a powerful fighting force in its own right - albeit a fanatical one that suffered heavy losses, particularly in Russia.\n\nThe ranks of what became the 3rd SS Panzer Division produced a number of Knight's Cross winners including the first enlisted man to win the award," SS-Sturmmann Fritz Christen."
Start building the armored units
Polizei Division

Polizei Division was formed in October 1939 from members of the Ordnungspolizei (regular police) that were conscripted into the unit.  Heinrich Himmler admitted in a speech to Waffen-SS officers that they were neither National Socialists nor SS men.

The divison was used for occupation duties in Poland before seeing some action in the invasion of France by taking part as a reserve unit in the fighting surrounding the Maginot Line.  It also fought on the Eastern Front, taking part in the advance towards Leningrad and later in the battles of Lake Ladoga. 

In 1943, it transferred to the Balkans where it was re-formed into a panzergrenadier division and was used for anti-partisan duties in Greece and the Banat region before being withdrawn to Slovakia in January 1945, and then on to the Danzig area. Evacuated by sea in April, it then fought on the Oder front north of Berlin," finally surrendering to US forces in May 1945. ! IMPORTANT ! This brigades in this unit will automatically be removed and upgraded following the historical changes to the division. Changing the names or removing any brigades will break the event chain."
9. SS-Panzer-Division 'Hohenstaufen'

The 9th SS Panzergrenadier Division Hohenstaufen was one of the later SS formations", formed in 1943 along with its sister-division," the 10th SS Panzergrenadier Division "Frundsberg" - constituting the II SS Panzer Corps.  Named after the Hohenstaufen dynasty", the division created a reputation for itself during the fighting in Normandy and during the ill-fated Operation Market Garden," made famous by the book and film "A Bridge Too Far."\n\nThe division's arguably most famous commander", also its first, was SS-Obergruppenführer Willi Bittrich," who commanded the division at Arnhem."
10. SS-Panzer-Division 'Frundsberg'

The 10th SS-Panzergrenadier Division Frundsberg was formed in 1943 along with its sister-division, the 9th SS Panzergrenadier Division Hohenstaufen.  Named for the 16th Century German Landsknecht commander Georg von Frundsberg, the division first made its mark fighting in Normandy, along with Hohenstaufen with which it made up the II SS Panzer Corps.  In late 1944, Frundsberg was based around the Dutch town of Nijmegen during the ill-fated Operation Market Garden and did much to stem the allied advance.\n\nPerhaps Frundsberg's most famous personality was hidden until very recently, the left-wing author Günter Grass," who was conscripted as a seventeen year old in late 1944."
12. SS-Panzer Division 'Hitlerjugend'

Known as the Baby Division," the 12th SS-Panzer Division "Hitlerjugend" was formed in late 1943 as part of a plan to develop a military formation made up completely of Hitler Youth members born in 1926.\n\nWith a mix of battle-hardened Leibstandarte veterans and ideologically-primed teenagers", the division soon developed a reputation for its bravery in the field, but also for an almost blind fanaticism that didn't exist among the older generations of Waffen-SS personnel.  Hitlerjugend forged its fearsome reputation in Normandy, and the young men within its ranks fought bravely until the final days of the war.  It's most famous commander was probably the most dashing senior officer in the Waffen-SS," Kurt "Panzermeyer" Meyer."
16. SS-Panzergrenadier Division 'Reichsführer-SS'

16. SS-Panzergrenadier Division Reichsführer-SS was formed in November 1943 when Sturmbrigade Reichsführer-SS" was upgraded to a division with Volksdeutsche added to the units.

A kampfgruppe (battlegroup) from the division fought the allied landings at Anzio while the rest took part in the occupation of Hungary.  The division fought in Italy as a unit from May 1944 until being transferred to Hungary in Feb 1945.

It surrendered to British forces near Klagenfurt"," Austria at the end of the war."
17. SS-Panzergrenadier Division 'Goetz von Berlichingen'

17. SS-Panzergrenadier Division Goetz von Berlichingen, named for the German knight, Gottfried Gotz von Berlichingen (1480-1562), was raised in October 1943 from replacement units and conscripts.\n\nIt saw action against Allied forces in Normandy from 10 June 1944 on, and suffered heavy losses.  The surviving units of the division refitted in the Saar region during September and reinforced from Heer and Waffen-SS stragglers.  It fought around Metz in October and November before once again retreating to the Saar," seeing action there in December.  It fought in Lorraine in early 1945 during the Nordwind offensive and in March it retreated towards Nuremburg.  The survivors finally surrendered to US forces in Bavaria at the end of the war."
11. SS-Freiwilligen Panzergrenadier Division 'Nordland'

11. SS-Freiwilligen-Panzergrenadier Division Nordland was formed in 1943 to combine all the Scandinavian and Dutch volunteer formations.  However, the Dutch did not end up in Nordland and instead it contained a majority of volksdeutsche (ethnic Germans) and a minority of Scandinavians.

The division was sent to Croatia in September 1943 for training where it also took part in anti-partisan duties.

Ordered to the Oranienbaum front near Leningrad in November and December 1943, it suffered heavy losses during renewed Soviet offensives.  The Division then fought on the Luga River and at Narva before retreating to the Tannenberg Line July 1944 where it remained until September when it retreated into Latvia and seeing action in the Kurland battles.  Then transferred to Pomerania in February 1945," it fought until 19 March when it was evacuated and sent to the Oder front."
5. SS-Division Wiking
SS-Division Wiking was formed Dec 1940 from SS-Standarte Germania.
Don't raise the unit.  We don't need it!
Kampfgruppe'Nord'

KG 'Nord' was created during February 1941 in Norway. Its first action took place in Finland on the Lapland Front in June 1941. After suffering heavy losses at Salla in July, it was withdrawn for retraining by experienced Finnish units.
7. SS-Freiwilligen-Gebirgs Division 'Prinz Eugen'

7. SS-Freiwilligen-Gebirgs Division Prinz Eugen formed in March 1942 from parts of the volksdeutsche in Croatia, Serbia, Hungary and Romania.

Mainly involved in anti-partisan duty, in September 1944, the Prinz Eugen division held a bridgehead open in the Vardar Corridor (Macedonia) allowing 350,"000 Germans escape encirclement by the Red Army but being badly mauled in the action.

It fought on to the end of the war."
8. SS-Kavallerie-Division 'Florian Geyer'

8. SS Kavallerie Division Florian Geyer was formed in October 1942 by expanding the SS-Kavallerie Brigade formed in 1941. It's lineage goes back to the SS-Totenkopf-Standarte formed in September 1939. The division was named after the Franconian Knight Florian Geyer (1490-1525), a supporter of Martin Luther and leader of the Germans in the Peasant Wars of 1522-1525.\n\nThe division saw action on the Eastern Front, the Balkans," and finally Hungary where it was destroyed."
13. Waffen-Geb.Div.der SS Handschar (kroat.Nr.1)

13. Waffen-Gebirgs-Division der SS Handschar (Fighting Knife) was formed from Bosnian Muslims. It was training in France when a small mutiny was incited by partisan infiltrators, but was put down by the remainder of the division.

In February 1944, it was sent to Bosnia where it fought against Communist partisans. In late 1944, during front-line fighting in Hungary, major desertions started when the Germans withdraw as many soldiers wanted to stay behind and protect their homes.

Fighting against overwhelming odds," the division was eventually pushed back into Austria."
Raise the unit in Brcko
14. Waffen-Gren.Div. der SS (galiz. Nr.1)

14. Waffen-Grenadier-Division der SS was formed in April 1943 from western Ukrainian volunteers.  At the front-line near Brody, Ukraine in June 1944, it was almost destroyed with only 3,000 men escaping encirclement.\n\nRebuilt and used against a Slovakian uprising later in 1944, it was then sent to Yugoslavia to fight Tito's partisans.
Raise the unit in Tarnow
15. Waffen-Grenadier-Div. der SS (lettische Nr. 1)

15. Waffen-Grenadier-Division der SS (lettische Nr. 1) formed in October 1943 from Lativan volunteers.  It was sent to the Eastern Front in November.

After the Soviet offensive of autumn 1944, it was sent to West Prussia to reinforce and recover.

Returning to the front in January 1945, the division continued fighting the Red Army until the end of the war.
18. SS-Freiwilligen Panzergrenadier Division 'Horst Wessel'

18. SS-Freiwilligen Panzergrenadier Division Horst Wessel was formed around a cadre from 1. SS-Infanterie-Brigade (mot) and included mainly Hungarian volksdeutsche.

It was used for anti-partisan duties until it being sent to the Eastern front.  Later it fought in Hungary and then Czechoslovakia where it was eventually destroyed.

The Division was named after the SA (Sturmabteilung) hero Horst Wessel," a German Nazi known for being the author of lyrics to the song "Die Fahne hoch" (Horst Wessel Lied) and for being glorified by the Nazi regime as a martyr in the early years of the Nazi party."
19. Waffen-Grenadier-Div. der SS (lettische Nr. 2)
19. Waffen-Grenadier-Division der SS (lettisches Nr. 2) was formed from Lativan volunteers.  It fought the Red Army on the Eastern Front through the end of the war in the Kurland pocket.
20. Waffen-Grenadier-Div. der SS (estnische Nr. 1)

20. Waffen-Grenadier-Division der SS (estnische Nr. 1) was formed in March 1944 from Estonian volunteers.  It fought on the Eastern front, including the great battle at Narwa in 1944, and was later evacuated from Estonia along with the rest of German forces.  It continued fighting in Silesia and later Czechoslovakia until the end of the war.
21. Waffen-Gebirgs-Division der SS 'Skanderbeg'

The 21. Waffen-Gebirgs-Division was an ethnic Albanian division. It never reached full strength and was highly unreliable," being plagued by desertions. The division was named after the  Albanian warrior hero Skanderbeg.

The unit fought partisans in Albania and Yugoslavia until being officially disbanded in November 1944.

Its remaining cadre fought alongside 7th SS Volunteer Mountain Division Prinz Eugen" as "Kampfgruppe Skanderberg."
Raise the unit in Pristina
22. SS-Freiwilligen-Kavallerie Division 'Maria Theresia'

22. SS-Freiwilligen-Kavallerie-Division Maria Theresia formed in May 1944 from SS-Kavallerie Regiment 17 (formerly in the 8. SS-Kavallerie-Div.).

In September 1944, as part of kampfgruppe, the division was sent to Romania.  Fighting until being encircled, one part managed to fight its way to the Harmas River, swimming across, and re-joined German forces.  The other part survived behind enemy lines, re-joining German forces on 30 October.

The division was then sent to Budapest in November 1944 where it was again encircled, but this time completely destroyed.  The division's name referred to Maria Theresa from the House of Habsburg, who had ruled Austria," Hungary and Bohemia in the 18th century."
23. Waffen-Gebirgs-Division der SS Kama (Kroat Nr. 2)

Adolf Hitler gave approval for the raising of a 2nd Croatian Waffen SS division on June 17," 1944.  The fledgling division was given the honorary title Kama (a short Turkish sword) and assigned the divisional number 23.\n\nThe full title of the division became 23.Waffen-Geb.Div. der SS "Kama" (kroatische Nr. 2)."
23. SS-Freiw.Panzergren.Div. 'Nederland'

The 23rd SS Volunteer Panzer Grenadier Division Nederland was a Germanic Waffen SS volunteer division comprising of Dutch volunteers. It saw action primarily on the Eastern Front.  In February 1945, part of the division, the 4th SS Volunteer Panzergrenadier Brigade Nederland was to be merged with the 11th SS Volunteer Panzergrenadier Division Nordland, but after protests from the Dutch National Socialist Movement, the Nationaal-Socialistische Beweging (NSB), it was formed into its own SS Panzer Grenadier Division," although its strength never reached more than a brigade.\n\nNederland was given the number "23" when the 23.Waffen-Geb.Div. der SS 'Kama' division was disbanded. The division fought on the Oder River and south of Berlin where it was caught in the Halbe pocket and ultimately destroyed."
24. Waffen-Gebirgs-Division der SS Karstjäger

24. Waffen-Gebirgs-(Karstjäger-)Division der SS was  formed from Karstwehr-Bataillon on 1 Aug 1944.  The latter had been fighting partisans in northern Italy since 1942. Comprised mainly of Italian volunteers but also of those from Slovenia, Croatia, Serbia, and the Ukraine, the division had considerable success performing anti-partisan duties before ending the war fighting against British forces.
25. Waffen-Grenadier-Div. der SS Hunyadi (Ungarische Nr.1)

25. Waffen-Grenadier-Division der SS Hunyadi (Ungarische Nr. 1) consisted of Hungarian volunteers.  It was still in training when the Red Army entered Silesia and it retreated to Bavaria and later to Austria.  Two combat-ready battalions remained in Silesia for about a week seeing heavy action.
26. Waffen-Gren.-Div. der SS (Ungarische Nr. 2)

26. Waffen-Grenadier-Division der SS (Ungarische Nr. 2) formed in 1944, was the second Hungarian SS-division to be formed.  It was still forming, and in severe lack of equipment, when it was forced to withdraw to Austria, apart from a battle group that was sent to Brno in Czechoslovakia.
27. SS-Freiwilligen-Grenadier Division 'Langemarck'

27. SS-Freiwilligen-Grenadier-Division Langemarck formed 19 October 1944 when 6. SS-Freiwilligen-Sturmbrigade Langemarck upgraded to division status and consisted of Flemish volunteers.\n\nFought on the Eastern front during the fighting at Narva.  It continued to fight but was forced into Germany.  Surrendered at Mecklemburg though some parts participated in the battle of Berlin.
28. SS-Freiwilligen-Grenadier Division 'Wallonien'

28. SS-Freiwilligen-Grenadier-Division Wallonien was formed when 5. SS-Freiwilligen-Sturmbrigade Wallonien was upgraded to a division.  It consisted of mainly Belgian volunteers from the Wallonia region in southern Belgium," but also some French and Spanish.\n\nIt fought on the Eastern front until the end of the war when parts of the unit managed to retreat to Denmark while the rest surrendered to the Soviets."
SS-Sturmbrigade R.O.N.A

Also known as Volksheer Brigade Kaminski after it's commander Bronislav Kaminski. RONA stands for Russkaya Osvoboditelnaya Narodnaya Armiya (Russian Peoples Liberation Army). It had it's orgins in the pro-german militia formed in the Bryansk area.\n\nA regiment of the brigade participated in the crushing of the Warsaw Uprising in 1944, committing numerous atrocities. It was intended to reform the brigade into the 29. Waffen-Grenadier Division der SS, but this was never completed. The unit was found to be too unreliable and undisciplined, and its commanders were shot by the Germans.
Waffen-Geb.Brigade der SS (tatar Nr.1)

Waffen-Gebirgs-Brigade der SS (Tatar Nr. 1), made up of Crimean Tatar volunteers," was formed out of the Tataren-Gebirgsjäger-Regiment der SS. The expansion to a brigade was delayed due to lack of equipment and the lack of interest from its commander. It was disbanded Dec 1944 and its men were transferred to the Osttürkischen Waffen-Verbände der SS as SS-Waffengruppe Krim (Crimea)."
1. Ungarische SS-Ski-Bataillon

1. Ungarische-SS-Schi-Bataillon (actually three battalions strong) was made up of volunteers from the mountain troops of the Hungarian army who swore an oath of loyalty to Adolf Hitler. Considered an elite unit it was granted Waffen-SS status equal that of German units. It saw heavy combat during the final months of the war.
29. Waffen-Grenadier-Division der SS (italienische Nr.1)

After the Warsaw uprising in 1944, 29. Waffen-Grenadier-Division der SS (russische Nr. 1) was disbanded and its number given to 29. Waffen-Grenadier-Division der SS (italienische Nr. 1) formed Sep 1944 from disaffected Fascists and Italian POWs who volunteered for SS duty.\n\nThe division saw action at Anzio, but was mostly used for anti-partisan duty.  They used Italian weapons, equipment, and uniforms with Waffen SS insignia.
30. Waffen-Grenadier-Div. der SS (russische Nr.2)

30. Waffen-Grenadier-Division der SS (russische Nr.2) was formed Aug 1944 from Schutzmannschaft Brigade Siegling (named for it's first Commander Hans Siegling), consisting mainly of Belarusians. In Jan 1945 it was redesignated Waffen-Grenadier-Brigade der SS (weissrutenische Nr.1)
31. SS-Freiwilligen-Grenadier Division

31. SS-Freiwilligen-Grenadier Division was formed in Oct 1944 from conscripted volksdeutsche (mainly from the Batschka region of Serbia/Hungary) around a cadre from the disbanded Kama division.\n\nIn November 1944, before it was properly trained or fully equipped,it was forced to engage the Soviets advancing into Hungary during which it suffered heavy losses. After refitting it saw action in Silesia during the final months of the war.
32. SS-Freiwilligen-Grenadier Division '30. Januar'

32. SS-Freiwilligen-Grenadier-Division 30. Januar was formed in January 1945 from a mixture of the remains of other units," staff and pupils from SS schools.  The division fought on the Oder-front and parts of it participated in the battle of Berlin.\n\nThe title of the division comes from the date when Adolf Hitler became the chancellor of Germany on 30 January 1933."
33. Waffen-Grenadier-Division der SS 'Charlemagne' (franzoesische Nr. 1)
It was formed when Waffen-Grenadier-Brigade der SS Charlemagne (franzoesische Nr.1) was expanded to a division by adding men from the various collaborationist organisations from France.
34. SS-Freiwilligen-Grenadier Division 'Landstorm Nederland'

34. SS-Freiwilligen-Grenadier-Division Landstorm Nederland was formed when SS-Freiwilligen-Grenadier-Brigade Landstorm Nederland was upgraded to a division.\n\nIt saw action in the Arnhem area and suffered major losses during heavy fighting in Apr 1945.
35. SS und Polizei-Grenadier Division

35. SS und Polizei-Grenadier Division was founded in Feb 1945 from SS-Polizei Brigade Wirth (first commander, Johannes Wirth). It consisted largely of police personel evacuated from France. The unit fought the soviet forces southeast of Berlin and was overrun and destroyed.
36. Waffen-Grenadier-Division der SS

36. Waffen-Grenadier-Division der SS formed Feb 1945 from SS-Sturmbrigade Dirlewanger but it's formation into a division was never completed. It had it's origins in SS-Sonderkommando Dirlewanger, a unit formed from convicted poachers and trained for anti-partisan duty. But by 1945 it consisted mostly of criminals, former POWs and all kinds of rabble.\n\nIt suffered from desertions and bad disipline and was rendered non-functional by the massive Red Army offensive, though elements continued to fight.
37. SS-Freiwilligen-Kavallerie Division 'Lützow'

37. SS-Freiwilligen-Kavallerie-Division Lützow formed Feb 1945 from remnants of Florian Geyer & Maria Theresia on the Hungarian-Slovakian border.\n\nMarch 1945 saw a kampfgruppe from Lützow sent to 6. SS-Panzer-Armee. It arrived 4 April and joined the I SS Panzerkorps Leibstandarte Adolf Hitler where it saw heavy action during the retreat through Austria," where it finally surrendered at the end of the war."
Osttürkischer Waffenverband der SS

Osttürkischer Waffenverband der SS was formed in 1944 as 1. Ostmuselmanisches SS-Regiment with the support of the Grand Mufti of Jerusalem, Hajj Amin al-Husseini, with the intention of expanding it to a division, Muselmanischen SS-Division Neu-Turkistan.\n\nThe men came from the Turkic units in the Heer that were disbanded (450th, 480th and I/94 Turkic battalions)," prisoners of war and men working in Germany."
Kaukasischer Waffenverband der SS

Kaukasischer Waffenverband der SS, also known as Freiwilligen Brigade Nordkaukasien, began forming late 1944 with volunteers from the Caucasus region, with the Frewilligen-Stamm-Division as a nucleus.
Waffen-Gren.Rgt. (Rumänis.Nr 1)\n\nWaffen-Gren.Rgt. (Rumänis.Nr 2)

Formed from Romanian volunteers following the Romanian defection, a Waffen-Grenadier Division der SS (rumänische Nr. 1) with the blessing of the Romanian Government-in-exile led by Horia Sima (leader of the Iron Guard or Garda de Fier)

Waffen-Grenadier-Regiment der SS (rum. Nr 2) was raised in Dollersheim, Austria, but in Apr 1945 it was apparent that not enough weapons were available and it was reformed as an anti-tank regiment, SS Panzer-Zerstoerer-Regiment (rumänische Nr 2).
SS-Totenkopf Division

SS-Division Totenkopf was formed Oct 1939 from concentration camp guards of the SS-Totenkopfverbände with the addition of officers from the SS-Verfügungstruppe (SS-VT) and men from SS-Heimwehr Danzig. It was initially held in reserve during the campaign in the west, but was soon sent to the front in Belgium. They suffered heavy losses compared to other units but managed to keep up the advance.\n\nIn 1943 it was reorganized as a Panzer-Division.
Freiw-korps der SS '(Serbis)

Also called Srpski Dobrovoljacki Korpus (Serbische Freiwilligenkorps). The German military Commander for Serbia approved the formation of a civil administration to be headed by Serbian General Milan Nedic.\n\nRealizing that this new government would need the means to maintain law and order and to combat the Communist-led insurrection which had already broken out across the land, the Germans granted permission on 15 September 1941 for the formation of a Serbian auxiliary volunteer corps in a strength of five battalions.
Waffen-Grenadier Regiment der SS (bulgarisches Nr 1)

Waffen-Grenadier Regiment der SS (bulgarisches Nr 1) was formed when Bulgaria joined the allies in Sep 1944. It was made up of 500 - 600 Bulgarian workers and soldiers who were in Germany at the time and was willing to keep fighting with Germany.\n\nThis unit was reformed as the SS Panzer-Zerstoerer-Regiment (bulgarisches) Apr 1945.
We need every man we can get!
1. Ungarisches SS-Sturmjäger Regiment

1. Ungarisches SS-Sturmjäger Regiment was formed on 8 January 1945 and is believed to have been made up of approximately 5,000 Hungarian volunteers (probably from Waffen-Schi Battalion der SS 25 and Waffen-Schi Battalion der SS 26) and was attached to IV. SS-Panzerkorps.\n\nDuring the retreat in March 1945 the different parts of the regiment lost contact with each other but continued fighting as independent companies.
SS-Regiment Ney

SS-Regiment Ney was formed as SS-Regimentsgruppe Ney at Súr south of Budapest on 20 October 1944 by Dr. Karoly Ney, 1st secretary of the Keleti Arcvonal Bajtársi Szoevetség (KABSz - Alliance of Eastern Front Veterans)," an far-right organization that supported the overthrow of Admiral Horthy.\n\nThis organization was the source of the first 300 Hungarian volunteers with weapons being provided from 22. SS-Freiwilligen-Kavallerie-Division Maria Theresia."
Raise the unit in Zirc
SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 4 'Ostmark'

SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 4 Ostmark was formed in Linz, Austria, in September 1938. A sturmbann attached to this unit was formed in Berlin Oct 1938," SS-Sturmbann Goetze.  This was however made an independent unit in July 1939 and moved to Danzig were it was used to form SS-Heimwehr-Danzig.\n\nOstmark was transferred to Prague October 1939 where it relieved SS-Standarte Der Führer which was made a part of SS-Verfügungs Division."
SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 5 'Dietrich Eckhart'

SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 5 Dietrich Eckhart (an early Nazi politician) was formed in Oranienburg September 1939 around a cadre from SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 2 Brandenburg.  It was the last Totenkopf-Standarte to be formed before the end of the war.
SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 7
SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 7 was formed in Brünn during September 1939 and transferred to Drammen (Norway) April 1940.\n\nYou will receive this unit when the SS Nord Division is formed.
SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 8

SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 8 was formed in Karkow November 1939 from parts of SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 4 Ostmark.  It was redesignated SS-Infanterie-Regiment 8 Feb 1941 and was used to form 1. SS-Infanterie-Brigade (mot) Apr 1941.
SS-Totenkopf-Standarte Kirkenes

SS-Totenkopf-Standarte Kirkenes (also SS-Totenkopf-Standarte K and SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 9) was formed in Kirkenes, Norway, in 1940 from parts of SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 9, SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 12 and SS-Sonderbataillon Reitz.
SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 10

SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 10 was formed in Buchenwald November 1939 from parts of SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 3 Thuringen.  It was transferred to Danzig April 1940 and Krakow May 1940.  It was redesignated SS-Infanterie-Regiment 10 February 1941 and was used to form 1. SS-Infanterie-Brigade (mot) in April 1941.
SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 14
SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 14 was formed in Buchenwald Apr 1940 from parts of SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 6, SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 9 & SS-Totenkopf-Rekreuten-Standarte.
SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 6
SS-Totenkopf-Standarte 6 was formed in Prague Sep 1939 and was the first Totenkopf-Standarte to be raised after the war broke out.\n\nYou will receive this unit when the SS Nord Division is formed.
38. SS-Grenadier-Division 'Nibelungen'

38. SS-Grenadier-Division Nibelungen was formed 27 March 1945 from SS-Junkerschule Bad Toelz, Begleit-Battalion Reichfuhrer SS, 2 Zollgrenzschutz Battaillons and a battalion of Hitlerjugend members.\n\nDuring April 1945, the division was 7 battalions strong and fought on the Danube River. It later fought a determined resistance versus the US 20th Armoured Division," through half dozen retreats as the front collapsed.  It fought on until the ceasefire was called on 5 May."
162nd Turkoman Division

The 162nd Turkoman Division was a military division that was formed by the German Army in May 1943. It drew its men from prisoners of war or from refugees who came from the Caucasus and from Turkic land further east.\n\nThe soldiers were trained at Neuhammer and then sent to Italy as Hitler did not trust them to be reliable enough to fight on the Eastern Front.  After some initial setbacks, the division proved to be quite effective.
369th Reinforced Infantry Regiment

The 369th Reinforced Infantry Regiment, also known as the Croatian Legion was a military unit of the Independent State of Croatia's Croatian Home Guard (Hrvatsko domobranstvo) which fought alongside the Wehrmacht on the Eastern Front.
392nd (Croat) Infantry Division

The 392nd (Croat) Infantry Division was a division of the Wehrmacht which accepted volunteers from the Independent State of Croatia.  It was commonly known as the Blue Division, and was established August 17, 1943 in Doellersheim, Austria.\n\nIt was commanded by Generalleutnant Johann Mickl, with the majority of the officers being German.  The division's uniforms were German, with a Croatian coat-of-arms on the right sleeve.  It participated in the clearing of partisans from the island of Korcula in the Adriatic.
American volunteers in the Wehrmacht

There were some US citizens who were members of the Wehrmacht, but no unit made up of American volunteers was ever raised (despite some claims about an 'American Free Corps' or 'George Washington Brigade').\n\nAccording to figures from the SS, five US citizens served in the Wehrmacht in May 1940, but after that date no numbers are available.
Welcome guys
Armenische Legion

The Armenian Legion (German: Armenische Legion) was the name given to the 812th Armenian Battalion, which was a foreign unit of the German Wehrmacht during World War II, comprised largely of Red Army POWs under the voluntary leadership of Drastamat Kanayan, Armenian politician and military commander.  The battalion was trained by SS officers.
Azerbaijani Legion

The Azerbaijani Legion, or in German, Aserbaidschanische Legion, was another of the foreign units of the Wehrmacht.  The Azerbaijani Legion was formed in December 1941 as the Kaukasische-Mohammedanische Legion (Muslim Caucasus Legion) and was re-designated during 1942 into two separate legions, the North Caucasian legion and the Azerbaijani legion.\n\nIt was made up mainly of former Azerbaijani POW volunteers but also volunteers from other peoples in the area.
Caucasian Muslim Legion

During World War II, hundreds of thousands of foreign peoples joined with Hitler's legions to bring their people into special status in Hitler's New Order.  Tens of thousands among them were Muslims, the majority of them from the Soviet Union.\n\nUnder the banner of the crescent and the swastika, these Soviet Muslims believed in becoming holy warriors to liberate their land.  But the end of this unholy alliance was a disaster for them.
Danish People's Defence

The Danish People's Defence (Danish: Dansk Folke Værn or Dansk Folkeværn) was a minor grouping of the Danish Schalburg Corps formed in 1943.\n\nIt was made up of civilians, some of whom were expected to provide financial backing.
Why not
Free Corps Denmark

Free Corps Denmark (Danish: Frikorps Danmark) was a Danish volunteer army corps created by the Danish Nazi Party (DNSAP) in cooperation with Germany to fight the Soviet Union.

On June 29,1941, days after the German invasion of the Soviet Union, the DNSAP's newspaper Fædrelandet proclaimed the creation of the corps.  Its formation was subsequently sanctioned by the democratically elected Danish government which authorized officers of the Royal Danish Army to join the unit.

The corps was disbanded in 1943.
Georgian Legion
The Georgian Legion was a Georgian military formation within the German army during World War II.  Their established aim was the restoration of Georgias independence from the Soviet Union.
Hilfswillige-'Hiwis'(volunteers)

Hiwi. The word entered into several languages during World War II when German troops enlisted volunteers from the occupied territories for supplementary service (drivers, cooks, hospital attendants, ammunition carriers, messengers, sappers etc.).  This term is often associated with collaborationism, and, in the case of the occupied Soviet territories, with anti-Bolshevism (and widely presented by Germans as such).\n\nSome Soviet hiwis were pressed into combat in the ranks of the German Army in desperate situations, such as with the German Sixth Army at Stalingrad, where they added up to about 25% (50,000) of the front-line strength.  Some German divisions had a higher ratio  for example," the 71st and 76th Infantry had parity between German and Hiwi manpower."
Indische Legion

The Legion Freies Indien, or the Indische Legion, variously known as the Tiger Legion, the Free India Legion, the Azad Hind Legion, and the Indische Freiwilligen-Legion Regiment 950 or the I.R 950 (Indisches Infanterie Regiment 950) was an Indian armed unit raised in 1941 and attached to the German Army (Wehrmacht Heer), ostensibly, according to the concept of an Indian Liberation force during World War II by Subhash Chandra Bose in Nazi Germany.
Kalmykian Voluntary Cavalry Corps

The Kalmykian Voluntary Cavalry Corps was a unit of about 5,000 Kalmykian volunteers who chose to join the German Armed Forces (Wehrmacht) in 1942 rather than remain in the Soviet Kalmykian Republic as the German Army retreated before the Red Army.\n\nIn 1943 Stalin subsequently declared the Kalmykian population as a whole to be German collaborators and had them deported to Siberia suffering great loss of life.
Legion of French Volunteers Against Bolshevism

The Legion of French Volunteers Against Bolshevism (French: Légion des Volontaires Français contre le Bolchévisme, or simply Légion des Volontaires Français, LVF) was a collaborationist French militia founded on July 8, 1941.  It gathered various Collaborationist parties, including Marcel Bucard's Mouvement Franciste, Marcel Déat's National Popular Rally, Jacques Doriot's French Popular Party, Eugène Deloncle's Social Revolutionary Movement, Pierre Clémenti National Collectivist French Party and Pierre Costantini's French League.\n\nIt volunteered to fight against the USSR on the Eastern Front. The Legion of French Volunteers (LVF) was officially known to the Germans as Infantry Regiment (Infanterieregiment) 638.
Ukrainian Liberation Army

Supported by General Kestring (who was responsible for formation of Eastern Legions) the UVV grew in size and by 1942 included up to 50,000 men.  Towards the end of the war UVV had reached 80,000.\n\nThe UVV was included as part of Wehrmacht and was supplied with a lot of German officers.
The Polnische Wehrmacht

The Polnische Wehrmacht (Polish: Polska Sila Zbrojna, English: Polish Army Forces) unofficially also called the White Eagle's Legion (Polish: Legion Orla Bialego)," were Wehrmacht forces composed of Polish volunteers.  Planned for Operations Weiser Adler and "Berta", supported by the Gauleiter Hans Frank , confirmed 23 October 1944 by OKH," and 24 October 1944 by Adolf Hitler."
Roland Battalion

The Roland Battalion was one of the first Foreign Legions in the Wehrmacht.  It was made up of ethnic Ukrainians and existed only briefly from March to August 1941.\n\nThe Battalion was set up by the Abwehr and organized by Ukrainian nationalist Richard Yary in March 1941, prior to the German invasion of the Soviet Union.  Its members had originally volunteered for duty in the Nachtigall (Nightingale) Battalion, but after training, members who could not meet the high expectations of the more exclusive commando unit were transferred into a separate entity which became the Roland Battalion.  Ex-Brandenburger Oberleutenant Dr. Hanz-Albrecht Herzner was placed in military command of the Battalion.
Russian Corps

The Russian Corps, the Russian Guard Corps, the Russian Corps in Serbia, the Separate Russian Corps, Russisches Schutzkorps Serbien) was an armed force that existed from 1941 to 1945 in Yugoslavia, predominantly composed of anti-Communist Russian emigres.\n\nIt fought in alliance with axis forces against partisans, and later against the Red Army.  An estimated 17,000 men went through its ranks, of which 10,000 became casualties.
Russian Liberation Army

Russian Liberation Army was a group of predominantly Russian forces allied with Nazi Germany during World War II. The RONA was organized by former Red Army general Andrey Vlasov, who tried to unite Russians opposed to the Communist regime.  Amidst the volunteers were Soviet prisoners of war, and White Russian émigrés (some of whom were veterans of the anti-Communist White Army during the Russian Civil War).  On 14 November 1944 it was officially renamed the Armed Forces of the Committee for the Liberation of the Peoples of Russia (VS-KONR).
Turkestan legion

Although Turkic peoples had been perceived initially as 'racially inferior', this attitude officially changed in the Autumn 1941, when the Nazis attempted to harness the anti-Russian sentiment of Turkic peoples in Russia for political gain.\n\nThe first 'Turkistan Legion' was mobilized in May 1942, originally consisting of only one battalion but was expanded to 16 battalions and 16,000 soldiers by 1943.  Under the Wehrmacht's command, these units were mobilized exclusively on the Western front, isolating them from the Red Army.
Volga Tatar Legion

The Volga-Tatar Legion (German: Wolgatatarische Legion) or Legion Idel-Ural (Janalif: Idel-Ural Legion) was a volunteer Wehrmacht unit composed of Muslim Volga Tatars, but also included other Idel-Ural peoples such as Bashkirs, Chuvashes, Mari people, Udmurt people, and Mordva.
Swedish Volunteers

Because Sweden was a strict neutral during WWII, other than during the short experience of the Winter War in 1939, it did not openly allow for recruitment into foreign armies.\n\nWhen Germany invaded the Soviet Union in 1941 its sentiments changed very little, although the Finns were allowed to garner volunteers once again.  Approximately 1,500 Swedes volunteered for service with Finland between 1941 and 1944.
Division Azul

The Blue Division (Spanish: División Azul, German: Blaue Division), or the 250th Infanterie-Division in the German Army, was a unit of Spanish volunteers that served in the German Army on the Eastern Front.
Thanks Spain

We are able to form some polizei brigades in Estonia.
Goliath transmitter

From 1943 to the end of World War II, Goliath was the main radio transmitter for submarine radio communications, and worked on frequencies between 15 and 60 kHz, the main working frequency being 16.55 kHz.

Using up to 1800 kW of power, the Goliath transmissions could be received by German submarines operating in a wide sea area, although they could not be received when the submarines were positioned in deep Norwegian fjords.  Goliath's transmissions could be received worldwide including submerged submarines in the Caribbean.

With such transmitters, we will be able to better hide our U-boats from the allies.

Defend them well
Operation Anton

Operation Anton (Fall Anton in German) was the codename for the military occupation of Vichy France carried out by Germany and Italy in 1942.  A German plan to occupy Vichy France had originally been drawn up in December 1940 under the codename of Operation Attila, and soon came to be considered as a single operation along with Operation Camellia, the plan to occupy Corsica.  Operation Anton updated the original Operation Attila, including different German units and adding Italian involvement.\n\nFollowing the Allied landings in French North Africa on 8 November 1942 (Operation Torch), Adolf Hitler could not risk an exposed flank on the French Mediterranean.  Following a final conversation with French Premier Pierre Laval, Hitler gave orders for Corsica to be occupied on 11 November 1942, and Vichy France the following day.
Occupy Southern France
First Helicopter in the world

The Focke-Achgelis Fa 223 Drache ('Dragon' in English) was a helicopter developed by Germany during World War II.  Noted for being the first helicopter to attain production status, Allied offensive actions limited production and only approximately 20 were made.  It was powered by a 1,000hp Bramo 323 radial engine which drove two, three-bladed, 12m rotors mounted on twin booms on either side of the 12m long cylindrical fuselage.\n\nYou have the possibility to massively build this helicopter. You will first use them as medical evacuation and then maybe you will be able to build a brigade of them.
This seems interesting
First prototype of Fa 223

The V1's first untethered flight was on 3 August 1940, after over 100 hours of ground testing.  In October it was flown to the test centre at Rechlin to be demonstrated, and while there set a top speed of 182 km/h (113 mph), a climb rate of 528 m (1,730 ft) per minute, and a maximum altitude of 7,100 m (23,000 ft).  Despite this, the Drache was nowhere near ready for military service, and Focke-Achgelis were told to accelerate their development programme.  An initial production order for 100 machines was promised.
Make a brigade of that
Air Cavalry reporting for duty!
We've managed to build an air cavalry brigade of the Focke-Achgelis Fa 223 Drache.\n\nUse it wise because you won't get another opportunity!
Armored Trains

Germany made use of armoured trains from the very beginning of the Second World War.  Extensive use was made of captured material, and new trains were built for the invasion of Russia in 1941.  Military success was followed by lengthening supply lines, and armoured trains were needed to protect the railways from partisan activity. Uses were attack, defence, patrol and maintenance of communications, even artillery support: there was a wide variety of potential roles for the armoured train.\n\nIn May 1942 the decision was made to create a standard train design - the BP42 - which, with a few improvements and modifications, was to serve to the end of the war.  Eleven BP42 trains were constructed, and several older trains were re-configured to approximately this standard, using existing rollingstock.
